data.title: Stronger Market Reaction Likely if U.S.-China Talks Fail to Deliver Results — Market Talk
data.description:
0730 GMT - Limiting the downside risks for Chinese markets and the yuan depend on the potential of fresh talks between the U.S. and China, writes Mansoor Mohi-uddin, chief economist at Bank of Singapore. Financial markets on Tuesday had a muted reaction to China's retaliatory tariffs of 10%-15% on select U.S. goods, but there's a chance of a stronger reaction down the line if negotiations don't see results, Mohi-uddin says. Should U.S. tariffs on China remain at 10% this year, the impact should be manageable, he notes, adding that the measures will trim about 0.5% from China's GDP growth this year from its 5.0% rate in 2024. However, should the tariffs be raised to 20%-30%, growth may fall closer to 4.0%, Mohi-uddin estimates. (kimberley.kao@wsj.com)

0725 GMT - Japanese stocks ended higher, led by auto stocks, as fears about U.S. tariffs subside. Toyota Motor gained 3.1% after it raised earnings projections and reported third-quarter results. Meanwhile, Honda Motor climbed 8.2% following news that Nissan's board is planning to reject Honda's terms for a combination of the two automakers. Nissan Motor fell 4.9%. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.1% to 38831.48. Investors are focusing on U.S. tariff-related developments as well as earnings. USD/JPY is at 153.16, compared with 154.34 as of Tuesday 5 p.m. Eastern time. The 10-year Japanese government bond yield rises one basis point to 1.285%. (kosaku.narioka@wsj.com; @kosakunarioka)

0717 GMT - The yuan may still face more downward pressure, Maybank's FX analysts say in a research report. "China remains the only country that President Trump has allowed tariff to take effect on," the analysts say. "Notwithstanding the fact that his trade policies and end goals remain murky at this stage, the developments thus far suggest that China is still taking the brunt of his trade policies," the analysts say. Taking into account the tariffs' deadlines, a scenario of an impasse on U.S.-China negotiations would probably prompt the PBOC to "relent" on USD/CNY fixings and allow USD/CNY to trend higher, the analysts add. USD/CNH is little changed at 7.2861. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0714 GMT - The impact of Trump's 10% tariff on Chinese exports on China's GDP growth this year looks manageable, Bank of Singapore chief economist Mansoor Mohi-uddin writes in a note. If the 10% levy is maintained for the rest of 2025, that would shave around 0.5% off China's GDP growth, he says. But if tariffs are raised to 20% to 30%, that would likely drag China's economic growth this year to 4.0% from 5.0% last year, he adds. That said, Beijing's retaliation, with targeted tariffs aimed at U.S. exports amounting to only $14 billion, leaves the door open for a potential deal with Washington to avert a broader trade war, he adds. (jiahui.huang@wsj.com; @ivy_jiahuihuang)

0704 GMT - The 'tariff can' has just been kicked down the road, with the idea of imposing levies on U.S. imports from its two closest neighbours still not off the table entirely, says Pepperstone's Michael Brown. "In fact, this whole saga could well rumble on until the start of April, when the review ordered by President Trump into U.S. trade policy is due to report back," the senior research strategist says in a note. Trump agreed to postpone the tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month after talks with the leaders of both countries. "Perhaps, it is at that point, that we will see tariffs shift from being used as a bargaining chip to further certain political aims, to actually being used as a measure to address trade imbalances," Brown says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0659 GMT - Japan, South Korea and Taiwan have dodged tariff bullets for now, but they shouldn't get too comfortable, Moody's Analytics economists say. The three appear obvious targets given their hefty trade surpluses with the U.S. One possible reason is security ties with the U.S. Another is the fact that Japan is among the U.S.'s biggest foreign investors. Korean and Taiwanese firms have been ramping up investment too. That's come at China's expense, aligning with the U.S. bid to curb its influence in supply chains, they add. But the mood could shift and tariffs could come. The economies also face collateral damage. Carmakers like Toyota and Kia have plants in Mexico, and Taiwanese and Korean chip and electronics producers in the U.S. face disruptions via trade barriers or surging production costs. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0649 GMT - South Korea's benchmark Kospi rose 1.1% to close at 2509.27 amid easing fears over U.S. tariffs. Foreign and institutional investors were net buyers. LG Energy Solution and Samsung SDI gained 3.6% and 3.4%, respectively, after the government prepared a new aid plan for the EV battery industry. Memory-chip maker SK Hynix added 4.0%. Mobile internet giant Kakao climbed 5.6% after agreeing to develop AI Products with OpenAI. Meanwhile, LG CNS, an IT service affiliate of LG Group, fell 9.9% on its stock exchange debut. USD/KRW settled 1.3% lower at 1,444.30 in Seoul onshore trading. South Korea's 10-year government bond yield was down 2.3 bps at 2.821%. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

0518 GMT - Hong Kong could see a turnaround in retail sales this year on an estimated 25% increase in visitors to the city, with CGS International analysts projecting retail sales gain at 5% for 2025. The city's retail sales by value fell 7.3% in 2024.The easing of visa policies for mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong and continued increase in foreign tourists have boosted Hong Kong's visitor numbers, they add. The opening of Kai Tak Sports Park in March and multiple major events including concerts and sporting events should also attract high-spending tourists in 2025 and encourage local consumption, they say. There were encouraging signs in higher visitor numbers from China and other countries over the Lunar New Year holiday, which have boosted hotel bookings and luxury spending, CGS International says. (jiahui.huang@wsj.com; @ivy_jiahuihuang)

0439 GMT - Japan's cash earnings jumped in December, while Moody's Analytics' Stefan Angrick sees little evidence of sustained real wage growth. At first glance, the data suggests things are turning around as monthly cash earnings rose solidly, the economist says, adding that the devil is in the details. Though nominal pay growth is picking up, the gains are uneven, and real cash earnings climbed only 0.6% on year, he says, describing it "a far more modest gain than the glossy nominal figure." The pay bump was also driven significantly by temporary factors, such as bonuses. Wage growth is likely to improve despite strong headwinds expected in 2025, including, but not limited to, a potential inflation spike, he adds. Much depends on the spring wage negotiations. If pay gains come in below 5%, that could delay the rate hikes, he adds. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0422 GMT - Hong Kong PMI data show continued concern among private sector firms about the year ahead as global uncertainty rises. The headline S&P Global PMI for January signaled only a modest improvement in business conditions and slipped to its lowest since September 2024. Weak external demand was the main growth constraint, says Tim Moore, economics director at S&P Global Market Intelligence. "Survey respondents noted subdued willingness to spend among clients amid concerns about the near-term global economic outlook, in particular the impact of potential U.S. tariffs." Export sales fell at the fastest pace since September 2024, while new business from Mainland China decreased to the greatest extent since April 2022. Despite an upturn in total new work, Hong Kong firms remain pessimistic about the year ahead, Moore says. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0402 GMT - Singapore dollar is steady against its U.S. counterpart in the Asian session amid caution over the latest tariffs from the U.S. and China. "We are only at the beginning of the tariff saga," Maybank analysts say in an FX Research & Treasury report. "It would be wise to be slightly more cautious as there is a likely limit to how much the USD can weaken," the analysts say. USD/SGD is little changed at 1.3524. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0339 GMT - The Bank of Korea may cut its policy rate later this month despite January's pickup in domestic inflation, Barclays economist Bum Ki Son writes in a note. Headline inflation accelerated to 2.2% from 1.9% in December, but the BOK may focus on soft core inflation and weak domestic demand, Son says. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, ticked up to 1.9% from 1.8% in December. BOK policymakers see forex-related pressures as limited and oil prices as a one-off shock, he notes. "As such, we believe inflation is unlikely to stop the BOK from cutting rates 25bp at its February meeting," he says. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

data.title: South Africa’s Private Sector Sinks Sharpest Since 2021
data.description:
The S&P Global South Africa PMI fell to 47.4 in January 2025, down from 49.9 in December, marking the sharpest contraction in the private sector since July 2021.

The decline was driven by weak client demand, leading to a sharp drop in new business at the fastest pace since March 2024.

Consequently, businesses reduced output at the steepest rate in three-and-a-half years.

Meanwhile, firms made progress in clearing backlogged work, prompting renewed job cuts and reductions in input purchases, particularly in services and construction.

On a positive note, supply chain pressures eased, as delivery delays moderated to a nine-month low.

Price pressures also softened, with input cost inflation slowing despite higher wages and import fees.

This led to a more measured rise in selling prices compared to previous months.

Looking ahead, business confidence improved, however, concerns over demand conditions persisted, limiting the extent of optimism.

data.title: IWOW Technology Buys Back 81,000 Shares
data.description:
IWOW Technology (SGX: NXR) repurchased 81,000 shares on Monday at SG$0.1897 each, totaling SG$15,368, according to a same-day filing on the Singapore Exchange.

The company has now bought back 258,100 shares, or 0.1% of its issued stock, under its current buyback mandate which allows it to repurchase around 26.3 million shares.

data.title: GSK Commences GBP2 Billion Share Buyback Program
data.description:
GSK announced a share buyback plan totaling 2 billion pounds sterling.

The pharmaceutical giant said with its 2024 results on Wednesday that the program will run for the next 18 months.

data.title: German Bund Yields Fall, Tracking U.S. Treasury Yields Lower — Market Talk
data.description: German Bunds are running into resistance ahead of the yield lows of the year, but shaky risk sentiment and a sanguine European Central Bank wage tracker should keep the momentum going, says Commerzbank Research's Michael Leister. "With the ongoing focus on trade wars and fragile risk sentiment we expect Bunds to stay bid," the head of interest rates strategy says in a note. That said, the air is getting thinner for Bunds as yields are approaching the lows recorded in the initial sessions of the year, Leister says. In addition, risk-off once again turns out to not be self-reinforcing, with equities stuck at the highs, he says. The 10-year German Bund yield falls 2.5 basis points to 2.374%, tracking U.S. Treasury yields lower, according to Tradeweb. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

data.title: Indri whisky maker Piccadily Agro shares hit 5% lower circuit as Q3 net profit declines 45%
data.description:
The shares of Piccadily Agro Industries shares dropped 5 percent to get locked in the lower circuit at Rs 784.35 apiece on February 5. This comes after the maker of Indri single-malt whiskey reported a 45 percent year-on-year drop in net profit for the quarter which ended on December 31.

Piccadily Agro Industries announced its results of the October-December quarter on February 5. The company reported a net profit of Rs 24.49 crore for the reported quarter, a fall of nearly 45 percent from the Rs 44.89 crore net profit reported in Q3 of the previous financial year.

The company's revenue from operations, however, rose 7 percent year-on-year to Rs 205.72 crore in Q3 of the current financial year, from Rs 191.91 crore reported in Q3 of FY24.

Piccadilly Agro's total income stood at Rs 208.32 crore in Q3 of FY25. This is nearly 8 percent higher than the Rs 191.99 crore total income reported in the year-ago period. Its total expenses meanwhile rose nearly 5 percent year-on-year to Rs 172.16 crore during the reported quarter.

Also read: Our LIVE blog on Q3 results

The company's earnings per share (EPS) fell to Rs 2.63 in Q3 FY25 from Rs 4.69 in Q3 FY24. Its distillery segment generated a revenue of Rs 183.91 crore in Q3 FY25, up from Rs 155.22 crore in Q3 FY24. However revenue generated from the sugar segment fell to Rs 21.8 crore in Q3 FY 25 from Rs 36.69 crore in Q3 FY24.Piccadilly Agro Industries was incorporated in 1994. The company's main business is in the sugar and distillery segments. It sells sugar, molasses, power and bagasse in the former and liquor, malt, carbon dioxide gas and ethanol in the latter segment.

data.title: PC Jeweller Turns to Profit in Fiscal Q3; Shares Jump 5%
data.description:
PC Jeweller booked a turnaround in fiscal Q3 with a consolidated attributable net profit of 1.48 billion Indian rupees against an attributable net loss of 1.98 billion rupees a year ago.

Earnings per share stood at 0.16 rupees compared with a loss per share of 0.43 rupees, according to a Tuesday filing to the Indian stock exchanges by the jewelry company.

Revenue from operations in fiscal Q3 surged to 6.39 billion rupees from 400.6 million rupees a year earlier.

Shares of the company were up 5% in recent trade.

data.title: FTSE 100 Seen Opening Lower Amid Trump Uncertainties — Market Talk
data.description: The FTSE 100 is expected to open 24 points, or 0.3%, lower, according to IG. The index closed down 12 points, or 0.2%, to 8570 points Tuesday. "On the equities front, sentiment is much less cheery this morning as Google [parent Alphabet] and AMD results released after the bell didn't enchant investors," Swissquote Bank analyst Ipek Ozkardeskaya says in a note. Meanwhile, safe havens remain in demand on growing global uncertainties under U.S. President Trump's "hectic lead," she says. On the economic data front, the focus will be on U.S. ADP private payrolls at 1315 GMT and U.S. ISM services at 1500 GMT. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

data.title: Balady Poultry Sets SAR1 Billion Strategic Expansion Investment Plan Through 2029
data.description:
Balady Poultry (SASE:9559) unveiled its strategic expansion plan for the 2025 to 2029 period to meet the growing demand for poultry products, achieve its goals, and maximize shareholder value.

The Saudi Arabia-based poultry farm operator plans to invest 1.14 billion Saudi riyals to develop a slaughterhouse and a factory to produce poultry meat, 600 broiler chicken coops, and two hatcheries, according to a Wednesday release.

The expansion will be financed through surplus cash, loans from the Agricultural Development Fund, and sharia-compliant Murabaha financing from commercial banks.

data.title: Harmony Gold Reports Five Deaths at Two Separate South African Mines
data.description:
By Ian Walker

Harmony Gold Mining said that five people died in two separate incidents in South Africa on Tuesday morning and that the causes of the accidents are currently under investigation.

The South African gold miner said Wednesday that two employees died following a mining incident at a development end at Doornkop Mine, in Soweto, Gauteng province. All blasting operations have been temporarily suspended at the mine, it said.

Separately a further three employees died following rock falls at Harmony's Joel Mine, near Theunissen in the Free State Province.

The company said that the relevant authorities have been kept fully informed of the incidents, adding that investigations into the incidents will be led by the Department of Mineral Resources and Energy, supported by labour representatives and mine management at each operation.

Write to Ian Walker at ian.walker@wsj.com

data.title: DCC Logs Growth in Fiscal Q3 Adjusted Operating Profit
data.description:
DCC said Wednesday that its group adjusted operating profit for the fiscal third quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, was "modestly ahead" of the prior-year period on a constant currency basis.

The British sales, marketing, and support services company affirmed its expectations for its fiscal full year's operating profit to increase.

data.title: GSK Posts Lower FY24 Profit; Turnover Up
data.description:
GSK said Wednesday that profit for full-year 2024 fell, while turnover rose year over year.

Profit attributable to shareholders for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 2024, was 2.58 billion pounds sterling, compared with 4.93 billion pounds earlier. EPS moved to 0.622 pound from 1.199 pounds.

The pharmaceutical giant's turnover was 31.38 billion pounds, compared with 30.33 billion pounds a year ago.

Meanwhile, the board declared a fourth-quarter dividend of 0.16 pound per share, payable April 10 to shareholders on record Feb. 21. It paid 0.16 pound per share a year ago. This takes the full-year dividend to 0.61 pound per share, up from 0.58 pound per share in the previous year.

GSK said it expects to pay a full-year dividend of 0.64 pound per share for 2025. Turnover for 2025 is expected to increase between 3% and 5%.

The company is targeting sales of more than 40 billion pounds by 2031. It also maintained its outlook for the period from 2021 to 2026, expecting sales growth of more than 7%.

data.title: Large trades totalling nearly Rs 100 crore in Rakesh Jhunjhunwala stock today; share price gains amid heavy volumes
data.description:
The shares of Star Health and Allied Insurance saw heightened activity on Wednesday, February 5, with multiple large trades worth a total of Rs 96 crore executed during the session. The stock was up 1.1 percent at Rs 443.1 as of 12:30 pm, supported by heavy volumes.

Heavy volumes, stock still way off 52-week high

Star Health witnessed a surge in trading volumes, with activity reaching 3.6 times its 10-day average by late noon. Despite the gains, the stock remains down 31.5 percent from its 52-week high of Rs 647, recorded on September 9, 2024. However, it has recovered 4.2 percent from its 52-week low of Rs 425.5, hit on January 29, 2025.

Over the past year, Star Health has lost 23 percent of its value, with its market capitalisation currently at Rs 26,000 crore.

Fundamentals and valuation checkTrailing twelve-month (TTM) EPS: Rs 13.41TTM Price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio: 33.03, lower than the sector P/E of 45.8Price-to-book (P/B) ratio: 3.78

data.title: Ferrari Cut to Equalweight From Overweight by Barclays Capital
Accumulate KEC International; target of Rs 930: Prabhudas Lilladher
data.description:
Prabhudas Lilladher's research report on KEC International

We revise our EPS estimates by -8.3%/-5.2% factoring in slower margin recovery amid higher revenue mix of non-T&D and upgrade the rating to ‘Accumulate’ from Hold due to recent sharp correction in the stock with a revised TP of Rs930 (Rs997 earlier). KEC International (KEC) reported a revenue growth of 6.8% YoY, while EBITDA margin expanded by 85bps YoY to 7.0%. The domestic T&D opportunity pipeline remains strong, driven by increasing momentum in the power sector. Internationally, T&D prospects are expanding across key regions, including the Middle East, Africa, CIS, and the Americas, with Saudi Arabia leading investments in energy transition and T&D infrastructure. SAE Towers continues to witness healthy demand; however, the depreciation of the Brazilian currency against the USD has tempered growth in this segment. Meanwhile, the Oil & Gas sector continues to face challenges due to tendering delays from Oil PSUs. Persistent labor shortages and collection delays in Water projects and Railways have prompted management to revise its topline growth guidance downward from ~15% to 12-14% YoY. In response, the company remains selective in Civil and Railway order bookings, prioritizing cash flow certainty and shorter execution cycles.

Outlook

We remain positive on KEC for the long term given its 1) strong order book, 2) healthy execution momentum, 3) robust T&D outlook, especially in renewable energy, and 4) expansion of Cables business. The stock is currently trading at a P/E of 17.7x/13.8x on FY26/27E earnings. We value the stock at a PE of 18x on Sep’26E EPS (same as earlier). Upgrade to ‘Accumulate’.

For all recommendations report, click here

Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by investment experts/broking houses/rating agencies on moneycontrol.com are their own, and not that of the website or its management. Moneycontrol.com advises users to check with certified experts before taking any investment decisions.

KEC International - 05022025 - prabhu

data.title: Zhenro Properties Group to Delist Senior Bonds Upon Maturity
data.description:
Zhenro Properties Group will delist its 7.35% senior bonds from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange upon maturity on February 5, 2025, according to a Tuesday filing with the bourse.

The company cited liquidity constraints and ongoing discussions on liability management as reasons for its inability to settle outstanding payments.

data.title: GSK Expects Further Profit Growth After Beating Market Views
data.description:
(07:00 GMT) *GSK PLC 4Q Sales Consensus Was GBP7.83B
(07:00 GMT) *GSK PLC 4Q Core EPS Consensus Was 20.6p
(07:01 GMT) *GSK PLC Declares 4Q Dividend of 16p
(07:02 GMT) *GSK PLC Issues GBP2B Buyback
(07:02 GMT) *GSK PLC Sees 2025 Turnover Growth of 3% to 5%
(07:03 GMT) *GSK PLC Sees 2025 Adjusted Operating Growth of 6% - 8%
(07:03 GMT) *GSK PLC Sees 2025 Adjusted EPS Growth of 6%-8%
(07:03 GMT) *GSK PLC Raises Mid-Term View
(07:04 GMT) *GSK PLC Sees 2031 Sales Outlook at More Than GBP40B
(07:05 GMT) *GSK PLC Had Seen 2031 Sales Outlook at More Than GBP38B
(07:28 GMT) GSK Expects Further Profit Growth After Beating Market Views

By Helena Smolak

GSK expects its sales and profit to grow in the new year after cancer treatments lifted sales and profit ahead of analysts' expectations in the fourth quarter despite lower vaccines sales on weak demand in the U.S.

The British pharmaceutical giant said Wednesday that for 2025 it expects sales to grow 3% to 5%. It also targets core operating profit and core earnings per share to grow between 6% and 8%. Targets are at constant exchange rates.

This compares with 2024 sales growth of 7%, core operating profit growth of 11% and core earnings per share growth of 10%.

Its fourth-quarter sales rose 4% at constant currencies to 8.12 billion pounds ($10.13 billion), above the 7.83 billion pounds that analysts had expected, according to a consensus polled by Visible Alpha.

Core operating profit, closely watched by analysts and investors, fell 10% at constant currencies to 1.43 billion pounds on lower-than-anticipated vaccine sales. Analysts had expected 1.385 billion pounds.

Its core earnings per share fell 10% at constant currencies to 23.2 pounds, above analysts' expectations of 20.6 pounds.

Write to Helena Smolak at helena.smolak@wsj.com

data.title: JonDeTech Sensors CEO to Depart
data.description:
JonDeTech Sensors (JDT.ST) Chief Executive Officer Leif Borg plans to step down from the position and leave the company.

The sensor technology company said in a Wednesday release that Borg has a six-month notice period and will remain with the company until the appointment of a successor.

The company will commence the search for a new CEO immediately.

data.title: TotalEnergies Earnings Jump On Quarter
data.description:
(07:04 GMT) *TotalEnergies Proposes Final Dividend for 2024 EUR0.85 a Share
(07:05 GMT) *TotalEnergies: Takes Full-year Dividend to EUR3.22 a Share
(07:06 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Adj EBITDA $10.53B
(07:07 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Net Pft $3.96B
(07:07 GMT) *Analysts Has Seen TotalEnergies 4Q Net Profit at $4.21B
(07:07 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Adj Net Profit $4.41B
(07:08 GMT) *Analysts Has Seen TotalEnergies 4Q Adj Net Profit at $3.94B
(07:08 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Cash Flow From Operating Activities $12.51B
(07:08 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Adj EPS $1.90
(07:09 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Hydrocarbon Production 2.43M BOE/D
(07:10 GMT) *TotalEnergies 4Q Hydrocarbon Production rose 1% vs 3Q
(07:10 GMT) *TotalEnergies Had Guided for 4Q Hydrocarbon at 2.4M to 2.45M BOE/D
(07:10 GMT) *TotalEnergies: 4Q European Refining Margin Maker Rose 68% Vs 3Q
(07:10 GMT) *TotalEnergies: 4Q European Refining Margin Maker $25.9 ton
(07:14 GMT) *TotalEnergies: Integrated LNG, Integrated Power Divisions Boosted 4Q Results
(07:16 GMT) *TotalEnergies Targets Buybacks of $2B a Quarter in 2025
(07:29 GMT) TotalEnergies Earnings Jump On Quarter

By Adam Whittaker

TotalEnergies reported a 72% jump on its fourth-quarter net profit, boosted by strong earnings in its integrated LNG and integrated power divisions, but still below analysts' expectations.

Net profit for the three months ended Dec. 31 rose to $3.96 billion, compared with analysts expectations of $4.21 billion, according to a Visible Alpha consensus.

The French oil and gas company also said it would target share buybacks worth 2 billion pounds ($2.50 billion) a quarter in 2025.

Write to Adam Whittaker at adam.whittaker@wsj.com

data.title: SSE Renewables Output Rose; Issues EPS Guidance
data.description:
(07:00 GMT) *SSE PLC Sees 2025 Adj EPS 154p-Adj EPS 163p
(07:01 GMT) *SSE: Renewables Output Up 26% Year-On-Year for the First Three Quarters
(07:02 GMT) *SSE Renewables Generation Output Over First Nine Mos Up 26%
(07:29 GMT) SSE Renewables Output Rose; Issues EPS Guidance

By Anthony O. Goriainoff

SSE said renewables energy output over its first three fiscal quarters rose and issued adjusted earnings per share guidance for the full fiscal year.

The U.K. energy group said Wednesday that renewables output over the nine-month period to Dec. 31 rose 26% to 9,253 gigawatt hours, reflecting a good operational performance against variable weather conditions, particularly in the third quarter.

SSE Thermal's output in the same period rose to 12,459 GWh from 10,797 GWh in the year-prior period.

SSE didn't provide full earnings guidance, but said that for the year ending March 31 it expects adjusted earnings per share within a range of 154 to 163 pence ($1.92-$2.03). In fiscal 2024 adjusted EPS was 158.5 pence.

In November, SSE said it was on track to deliver fiscal 2027 adjusted EPS of between 175 pence and 200 pence.

"As we look to the opportunities presented by decarbonization our focus remains on capital discipline, strategic delivery and the efficient operation of our value-creating assets," the company said.

Write to Anthony O. Goriainoff at anthony.orunagoriainoff@dowjones.com

data.title: Stronger Market Reaction Likely if U.S.-China Talks Fail to Deliver Results — Market Talk
data.description: Limiting the downside risks for Chinese markets and the yuan depend on the potential of fresh talks between the U.S. and China, writes Mansoor Mohi-uddin, chief economist at Bank of Singapore. Financial markets on Tuesday had a muted reaction to China's retaliatory tariffs of 10%-15% on select U.S. goods, but there's a chance of a stronger reaction down the line if negotiations don't see results, Mohi-uddin says. Should U.S. tariffs on China remain at 10% this year, the impact should be manageable, he notes, adding that the measures will trim about 0.5% from China's GDP growth this year from its 5.0% rate in 2024. However, should the tariffs be raised to 20%-30%, growth may fall closer to 4.0%, Mohi-uddin estimates. (kimberley.kao@wsj.com)

data.title: Arm's Earnings Could Shed Light on Tech's Big Question: What's Next for AI After DeepSeek? — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Tae Kim

Investors eager to hear what the DeepSeek moment means for the AI chip industry will be tuning in on Wednesday, when Arm Holdings discloses its quarterly results.

Arm makes money by licensing its chip designs to semiconductor companies and smartphone makers. That means its management is in a good position to assess the impact of the Chinese AI model on the industry.

Results for Arm's fiscal third quarter are due after the close.

The consensus among analysts is for Arm to report December quarter revenue of $949 million with adjusted earnings per share of 34 cents. For the current quarter, analysts' consensus estimates are for revenue of $1.22 billion and earnings per share of 52 cents, according to FactSet.

On Friday, KeyBanc analyst John Vinh reaffirmed his Overweight rating and $195 price target on Arm. The analyst believes the results won't be a disappointment.

"We expect ARM to post in line results and in line guidance, driven by continued strength in AI and traditional server," he wrote.

Arm's latest advanced chip technology, called Armv9, generates significantly higher royalty rates than its previous Armv8. It is also making progress in high-end cloud server processors. Customers such as Microsoft and Nvidia are making chips with more than 100 "cores" using Arm's designs.

Arm shares are up 128% over the past 12 months, compared with the 9% gain for the iShares Semiconductor ETF.

Write to Tae Kim at tae.kim@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: British Utility SSE Forecasts Good Operational Performance for FY25
data.description:
SSE said Wednesday that it expects adjusted EPS for fiscal 2025 to signify good operational performance against variable weather conditions.

In its trading update for the fiscal third quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, the British utility company said it expects adjusted EPS for the fiscal year to be between 1.54 pounds sterling and 1.63 pounds. Adjusted EPS for fiscal 2024 amounted to 1.585 pounds.

data.title: Happiest Minds Technologies' Consolidated Net Proifit Falls in Fiscal Q3
data.description:
Happiest Minds Technologies said its consolidated net profit dropped to 501.0 million Indian rupees in the fiscal third quarter from 596.2 million rupees a year ago, according to a Tuesday filing with the Indian exchanges by the IT company.

Earnings per share during the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, slipped to 3.33 rupees compared with 3.96 rupees a year earlier.

Revenue from operations in fiscal Q3 increased year on year to 5.31 billion rupees from 4.10 billion rupees, according to the filing.

data.title: Assa Abloy Reports Higher FY24 Net Income, Sales
data.description:
Assa Abloy (ASSA-B.ST) said Wednesday its net income and sales for the full year 2024 jumped year over year.

Net income attributable to shareholders for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 2024, was 15.64 billion kronor, compared with 13.63 billion kronor a year ago. EPS moved to 14.09 kronor from 13.54 kronor.

The Swedish access systems company's sales were 150.16 billion kronor, compared with 140.72 billion kronor earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting 149.62 billion kronor in sales, 15.53 billion kronor in net income, and 14.26 kronor in EPS.

Meanwhile, the board proposed a dividend of 5.90 kronor per share to be distributed in two equal installments. It paid a dividend of 5.40 kronor per share a year ago.

data.title: Nikkei Rises 0.1%, Led by Auto Stocks — Market Talk
data.description: Japanese stocks ended higher, led by auto stocks, as fears about U.S. tariffs subside. Toyota Motor gained 3.1% after it raised earnings projections and reported third-quarter results. Meanwhile, Honda Motor climbed 8.2% following news that Nissan's board is planning to reject Honda's terms for a combination of the two automakers. Nissan Motor fell 4.9%. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.1% to 38831.48. Investors are focusing on U.S. tariff-related developments as well as earnings. USD/JPY is at 153.16, compared with 154.34 as of Tuesday 5 p.m. Eastern time. The 10-year Japanese government bond yield rises one basis point to 1.285%. (kosaku.narioka@wsj.com; @kosakunarioka)

data.title: Global Forex and Fixed Income Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering FX and Fixed Income. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

0725 GMT - Japanese stocks ended higher, led by auto stocks, as fears about U.S. tariffs subside. Toyota Motor gained 3.1% after it raised earnings projections and reported third-quarter results. Meanwhile, Honda Motor climbed 8.2% following news that Nissan's board is planning to reject Honda's terms for a combination of the two automakers. Nissan Motor fell 4.9%. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.1% to 38831.48. Investors are focusing on U.S. tariff-related developments as well as earnings. USD/JPY is at 153.16, compared with 154.34 as of Tuesday 5 p.m. Eastern time. The 10-year Japanese government bond yield rises one basis point to 1.285%. (kosaku.narioka@wsj.com; @kosakunarioka)

0717 GMT - The yuan may still face more downward pressure, Maybank's FX analysts say in a research report. "China remains the only country that President Trump has allowed tariff to take effect on," the analysts say. "Notwithstanding the fact that his trade policies and end goals remain murky at this stage, the developments thus far suggest that China is still taking the brunt of his trade policies," the analysts say. Taking into account the tariffs' deadlines, a scenario of an impasse on U.S.-China negotiations would probably prompt the PBOC to "relent" on USD/CNY fixings and allow USD/CNY to trend higher, the analysts add. USD/CNH is little changed at 7.2861. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0714 GMT - The impact of Trump's 10% tariff on Chinese exports on China's GDP growth this year looks manageable, Bank of Singapore chief economist Mansoor Mohi-uddin writes in a note. If the 10% levy is maintained for the rest of 2025, that would shave around 0.5% off China's GDP growth, he says. But if tariffs are raised to 20% to 30%, that would likely drag China's economic growth this year to 4.0% from 5.0% last year, he adds. That said, Beijing's retaliation, with targeted tariffs aimed at U.S. exports amounting to only $14 billion, leaves the door open for a potential deal with Washington to avert a broader trade war, he adds. (jiahui.huang@wsj.com; @ivy_jiahuihuang)

0704 GMT - The 'tariff can' has just been kicked down the road, with the idea of imposing levies on U.S. imports from its two closest neighbours still not off the table entirely, says Pepperstone's Michael Brown. "In fact, this whole saga could well rumble on until the start of April, when the review ordered by President Trump into U.S. trade policy is due to report back," the senior research strategist says in a note. Trump agreed to postpone the tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month after talks with the leaders of both countries. "Perhaps, it is at that point, that we will see tariffs shift from being used as a bargaining chip to further certain political aims, to actually being used as a measure to address trade imbalances," Brown says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0659 GMT - Japan, South Korea and Taiwan have dodged tariff bullets for now, but they shouldn't get too comfortable, Moody's Analytics economists say. The three appear obvious targets given their hefty trade surpluses with the U.S. One possible reason is security ties with the U.S. Another is the fact that Japan is among the U.S.'s biggest foreign investors. Korean and Taiwanese firms have been ramping up investment too. That's come at China's expense, aligning with the U.S. bid to curb its influence in supply chains, they add. But the mood could shift and tariffs could come. The economies also face collateral damage. Carmakers like Toyota and Kia have plants in Mexico, and Taiwanese and Korean chip and electronics producers in the U.S. face disruptions via trade barriers or surging production costs. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0649 GMT - South Korea's benchmark Kospi rose 1.1% to close at 2509.27 amid easing fears over U.S. tariffs. Foreign and institutional investors were net buyers. LG Energy Solution and Samsung SDI gained 3.6% and 3.4%, respectively, after the government prepared a new aid plan for the EV battery industry. Memory-chip maker SK Hynix added 4.0%. Mobile internet giant Kakao climbed 5.6% after agreeing to develop AI Products with OpenAI. Meanwhile, LG CNS, an IT service affiliate of LG Group, fell 9.9% on its stock exchange debut. USD/KRW settled 1.3% lower at 1,444.30 in Seoul onshore trading. South Korea's 10-year government bond yield was down 2.3 bps at 2.821%. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

0518 GMT - Hong Kong could see a turnaround in retail sales this year on an estimated 25% increase in visitors to the city, with CGS International analysts projecting retail sales gain at 5% for 2025. The city's retail sales by value fell 7.3% in 2024.The easing of visa policies for mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong and continued increase in foreign tourists have boosted Hong Kong's visitor numbers, they add. The opening of Kai Tak Sports Park in March and multiple major events including concerts and sporting events should also attract high-spending tourists in 2025 and encourage local consumption, they say. There were encouraging signs in higher visitor numbers from China and other countries over the Lunar New Year holiday, which have boosted hotel bookings and luxury spending, CGS International says. (jiahui.huang@wsj.com; @ivy_jiahuihuang)

data.title: Global Equities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Equities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

0725 GMT - Japanese stocks ended higher, led by auto stocks, as fears about U.S. tariffs subside. Toyota Motor gained 3.1% after it raised earnings projections and reported third-quarter results. Meanwhile, Honda Motor climbed 8.2% following news that Nissan's board is planning to reject Honda's terms for a combination of the two automakers. Nissan Motor fell 4.9%. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.1% to 38831.48. Investors are focusing on U.S. tariff-related developments as well as earnings. USD/JPY is at 153.16, compared with 154.34 as of Tuesday 5 p.m. Eastern time. The 10-year Japanese government bond yield rises one basis point to 1.285%. (kosaku.narioka@wsj.com; @kosakunarioka)

0657 GMT - Grab's growth drivers are intact, and its adjusted Ebita will likely surge in 2025, driven by margin expansion, HSBC analysts write in a note. Grab is likely to strengthen its leadership position in ride-hailing and deliveries, as it invests into products to help expand its total addressable market with affordable products, they say. However, as the priority will be on new product initiatives, cross-selling and lending products, HSBC trims earlier margin estimates and reduces its adjusted Ebitda projection by 2%-5% for 2025-2026. HSBC lowers its target price to $5.45 from $5.50 but upgrades its stock rating to buy from hold as the stock offers 20% upside, and valuations have become attractive after the recent price correction. (kimberley.kao@wsj.com)

0655 GMT - Chinese AI company DeepSeek's breakthrough is unlikely to hurt demand in the short-term, although the market will likely cut multiples to price on uncertainties in the longer term, according to Julius Baer analysts in an emailed commentary. The market is debating on the long-term impact, as optimists argue that a lower entry barrier would attract new players, which should boost semiconductor demand, they write. "We do not expect much weakness in the near-term demand," the analysts note. They add that long-term demand will be determined by changes in AI-driven computing needs, such as inference, noting that such demand could offset the possibly lower computing demand in training. DeepSeek's development marks a major evolution, though not entirely a revolution, in artificial intelligence, they say. (tracy.qu@wsj.com)

0649 GMT - Thai Credit Bank appears confident in lowering credit costs in 2025, CGS International's Weerapat Wonk-Urai says, citing management commentary at an analysts' briefing. Management highlighted the bank's improving debt collection capabilities, supported by its front office staff helping with loan collections as soon as the loans become overdue, the analyst says in a research report. Also, the bank sold non-performing loans worth THB1.9 billion last year and plans to sell THB1.4 billion worth of NPLs this year, the analyst adds. The brokerage raises the stock's target price to THB26.12 from THB26.00 with an unchanged add rating. Shares are 1.0% lower at THB19.00. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0511 GMT - The U.S. Postal Services will likely need time to sort out how to implement new the tariff policy before resuming acceptance of Chinese packages, according to Chelsey Tam, senior equity analyst at Morningstar in an email. The process poses a significant challenge, given that in 2024, an estimated 4 million daily packages arrived in the U.S. under the de minimis rule, which allows low-value shipments to bypass duties and custom scrutiny, Tam says. The Trump administration revoked this exemption for China as part of broader tariff measures. Among Chinese e-commerce players, PDD Holdings will be hurt as its overseas e-commerce platform Temu has a significant exposure in the U.S., the analyst notes. (tracy.qu@wsj.com)

data.title: Market Chatter: Singapore Unlikely to be Direct Target in US-China Trade War, Says Foreign Minister
data.description:
Singapore is unlikely to be directly targeted in the escalating trade tensions between the US and China, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday, citing Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan.

Speaking to parliament on Tuesday, Balakrishnan highlighted the US's trade surplus with Singapore, suggesting the city-state may be shielded from direct tariff measures.

Total trade between the US and Singapore exceeded $131 billion in 2023, the report said.

However, Balakrishnan cautioned that the broader trade war could still have repercussions for Singapore, according to the report.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: NTN Swings to Nine-Month Loss
data.description:
NTN posted an attributable loss of 8.25 billion yen for the nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024, compared with an attributable profit of 7.68 billion yen in the year-ago period.

Basic loss per share was 15.56 yen, compared with earnings per share of 14.47 yen in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year, a Tuesday bourse filing said.

The bearing and precision machinery manufacturer saw a decline in net sales to 615.5 billion yen from 620.5 billion yen a year prior.

The company forecasts an attributable loss of 16 billion yen, loss per share of 30.18 yen, net sales of 815 billion yen, and a final dividend of 5.5 yen per share for the fiscal year ending March 31.
